description: From Middle English thirl, thiril, from Old English þyrel (“hole”), from Proto-West Germanic *þurhil, from Proto-Germanic *þurhilą (“hole, opening”), from Proto-Indo-European *tr̥h₂kʷelo- which is *tr̥h₂kʷe + *-lo (equivalent to through +‎ -le) from *terh₂-. Related to thrill, drill.

entries.meaning: (archaic or dialectal) A hole, an aperture, especially a nostril.
(dialectal) A low door in a dry-stone wall to allow sheep to pass through; a smoot.
(mining, possibly obsolete) A short communication between adits in a mine.
(mining, possibly obsolete) A long adit in a coalpit.

description: From Middle English thirlen, thurlen, thorlen, from Old English þȳrlian (“to pierce”), from the noun (see above).

verbs.description: thirl (third-person singular simple present thirls, present participle thirling, simple past and past participle thirled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, possibly obsolete) To pierce; to perforate, penetrate, cut through.
examples: But yet his hardnesse savde him not against the piercing dart.
For hitting right betweene the scales that yeelded in that part
Whereas the joynts doe knit the backe, it thirled through the skin,
And pierced to his filthy mawe and greedy guts within.

entries.meaning: (transitive, mining, obsolete) To drill or bore; to cut through, as a partition between one working and another.

description: Uncertain. Perhaps a blend of throw +‎ hurl.

verbs.description: thirl (third-person singular simple present thirls, present participle thirling, simple past and past participle thirled)

examples: And many Authours doe in this manner wound the protection of their cause, by over-rashly running against that which they take hold-of, thirling [translating lanceant] such darts at their enemies, that might with much more advantage be cast at them.

verbs.description: thirl (third-person singular simple present thirls, present participle thirling, simple past and past participle thirled)

entries.meaning: (historical, transitive) To legally bind (a tenant) to the use of one's own property as an owner.
